user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketListen:
```c
int32 OS_SocketListen(osal_id_t sock_id)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        /* This call is only applicable to stream sockets */
        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID || stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_STREAM)
        {
            /* Not a stream socket */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_BOUND) == 0)
        {
            /* Socket must be bound to an address already */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else if ((stream->stream_state & (OS_STREAM_STATE_LISTENING | OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED)) != 0)
        {
            /* Socket must be neither listening nor connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketListen_Impl(&token);

            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                stream->stream_state |= OS_STREAM_STATE_LISTENING;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketListen:
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_SocketListen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             os_result;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_result = listen(impl->fd, 10);
    if (os_result < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("listen: %s\n", strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The remaining code fragments are not reported because they either already use const where appropriate or they necessarily require a mutable (non-const) pointer: - OS_ObjectIdGetById(..., OS_object_token_t *token) and OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token) modify the token object as part of the object-id transaction API, so the pointer cannot be const. - The local variable 'token' is passed by address to the above functions and is legitimately mutable. - The checks of stream fields (socket_domain, socket_type, stream_state) are interleaved with a later write to stream->stream_state; since the object is modified in this function, the stream pointer cannot be made const for the whole function without refactoring (e.g., using a separate const pointer for reads). - Declarations and uses that are not pointer types (e.g., return_code, token as a value) are not relevant to Rule 8.13. - The function prototypes and calls that already use const-qualified pointers (where present) are compliant and do not need further investigation. These reasons explain why other fragments were not included; the listed suspicious fragments should be investigated to determine whether any of those pointers or macro usages could and should be const-qualified (or otherwise refactored) to conform with MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
